awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Governance, Organizational Complexity, and the Role of Pastoral Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

This doctoral dissertation research project explores whether barriers to governance could be influenced by the incorporation of disparate pastoral communities into processes of governance to service the dietary and mobility needs of herders and livestock. This project is relevant to research on nomadic pastoralism and mobile societies, and is especially pertinent to studies dealing with the relationships between governance, mobility, and herding at the community level. This is an immediate concern currently, as modern herders everywhere grapple with globalization, forced sedentarization, and reduced mobility due to international borders, environmental change and pasture degradation. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in archaeology in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the project would enhance public understanding of science and the scientific method by broadly disseminating its findings.

Using two existing models of state formation, this research assesses hypotheses for a decentralized and centralized political structure based on changes in human and livestock diet and mobility patterns through time. Data for this analysis comes excavations at two cemeteries  and stable (δ13C and δ15N) and radiogenic (87Sr/86Sr) isotope analyses of human and sheep skeletal remains. This project holds promise to generate insights from an understudied area, elucidate unique endogenous and indigenous forms of complex political organization, and evaluate the veracity of historical documents. Such findings would highlight the variability that exists in global forms of pre-industrial political complexity and reinforce the broader anthropological need to examine data generated from patterns of human organization that are not agriculture-centric.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching research goal of the archaeological project at the Shiriin Chuluu microregion in southeastern Mongolia is to provide a better understanding of the indigenous political institutions and state formation processes of ancient nomads. Because historic accounts of these groups come almost entirely from sedentary agriculturalists, archaeological data often represent the only lines of direct evidence to study the past lives of nomads. With this in mind, I am building an archaeological case study on the rise of the Xiongnu Empire (c.250 BC-150 AD), the first state formed by nomads in eastern Eurasia and the direct rivals of the Qin (221–206 BC) and Han (202 BC–220 AD) Dynasties of Central China. The Xiongnu Empire represents a foundational nomadic state that served as a precursor to later empires such as the Mongols and as such, provides the perfect context to study the development and implementation of nomadic state building and governance.

Shiriin Chuluu is located towards the outskirts of the empire, nearly 1000 km away from north-central Mongolia, the heartland of the Xiongnu. This means that at some point in the microregion’s history, the Xiongnu came in and made it part of their territory. To understand the process by which this occurred and the effect that “becoming Xiongnu” had on the nomads at Shiriin Chuluu, my project aims to reconstruct the diet and mobility patterns of nomads and livestock in the microregion prior to, during, and after the Xiongnu Empire. To this end, I am using stable carbon (δ13C) and nitrogen (δ15N) and radiogenic strontium (87Sr/86Sr) isotope data derived from Early Iron Age (c.1000-400 BC) and Xiongnu Period human and livestock (sheep, goat, cattle, and horse) skeletal remains recovered from graves. These data will provide an understanding of how the movement of local herders and their access to pastoral resources were affected by the rise of the Xiongnu Empire.

Support from the National Science Foundation (NSF) Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement (DDRI) grant went towards funding fieldwork at Shiriin Chuluu in the summer of 2022. During this field season my research team and I planned to excavate Slab Graves (c.1100-400 BC) and Xiongnu Period ring graves in order to recover human and livestock bones for later isotopic analyses. In this regard, the field season was quite successful. We excavated four Early Iron Age graves and four Xiongnu Period graves and found human and livestock skeletal remains in every context. After the field season, a portion of these bones were exported from Mongolia to Trent University (Peterborough, Ontario), where I isotopically analyzed the samples in the fall and winter of 2022. In addition to accomplishing the stated research goals of the grant, the excavation team also made two notable finds in the Xiongnu graves. The first is the discovery of a left hindlimb bone (metatarsal) from a Mongolian gazelle (Procapra gutturosa). This find is worth mentioning because skeletal remains of wild animals are rarely found in burial contexts in Mongolia or anywhere else in the world. The second find is the documentation of dog remains (Canis familiaris) in two of the Xiongnu ring graves. While dog bones have been recorded in Xiongnu Period mortuary and habitation contexts in northern Mongolia and Transbaikalia, dog remains are not well attested to in the Gobi Desert. For Shiriin Chuluu specifically, the gazelle and dog bones represent the first documented instances of such finds.

Beyond the scientific research objectives, I had two other important goals for this field season. The first was to directly communicate and interact with the community around Shiriin Chuluu in order to ensure that local stakeholders understood why we were there and what we were doing. To accomplish this goal, my team spoke directly to individual families in the area about our project, we met with and presented our findings to the heads of the local government at Altanshiree (the county seat), and I gave an onsite interview to a local news program and walked the news crew through an in-progress excavation of a Xiongnu ring grave. The other goal for the field season was to provide training and experience to Mongolian undergraduates in archaeological excavation, documentation, and cataloging techniques. To achieve this, I worked directly with ten undergraduate students from the National Teaching University of Mongolia. They received experience and training in excavating and documenting graves using a total station, commercial drone, photogrammetry, and a drawing pad loaded with Adobe illustrator. These techniques are becoming fairly standard across the globe and for the students on my project, this was their first exposure to these archaeological practices. After the completion of fieldwork, three of the students assisted me with cataloging the recovered artifacts. This provided an opportunity to teach them the basics of artifact documentation, database management, as well as animal and human skeletal analysis.
